The problem is that raising animals for slaughter is not predation.
If humans were predating, as in tracking wild animals with their eyes & noses, killing them with their teeth & claws, that is predation.
Raising captive-bred vast lots of sentient, intelligent animals for slaughter is an entirely different matter. Vegans are correct to dissent & moralize over the horror of animal factories, it is an ideal we should heed & endeavor to emulate to whatever extent possible.

In any food web on earth, virtually every organism is ultimately consumed alive by another organism, with the exception of a few top predators such as great white sharks and lions, or the few organisms simply too large to be eaten, such as large whales.  Even among these species the young are susceptible to predation.  Prehistoric humans were near, but not at the top of their food webs. With the advent of culture and civilization we have, with a few rural exceptions, eliminated or isolated our predators, and thus moved to the top of our food webs.  This is entirely natural and ethical since essentially every sentient organism (and many plants) engage in active predator avoidance.  Cruelty in predation is the norm, and indeed, only humans would even recognize the notion of cruelty in the act of acquiring food.  As ethical beings it is appropriate for humans to define norms in the way we harvest other animals for food that minimize cruelty as we ourselves experience it and define it.  And those norms can be expected to evolve over time.  But I see no intrinsic ethical imperative to extricate ourselves from predatory food webs.  Humans are members of a large branch of primates that kill animals to eat meat as part of their diet, and we are in company with a vast number of other such species.  I respect vegans and vegetarians as I do any other ethically motivated or religious group.  But their beliefs do not mark the non-negotiable baseline of human ethical behavior.

Stack ranking is fair. Trying to get the best out of your employees is fair. However, large corporations can take it too far. They can exploit young, inexperienced, insecure employees and work them to the bone. The employees are too inexperienced (or too desperate) to know better.

The unfortunate part is that working excessive hours is bad for the employee (yes), but what really suffers is the community and the country as a hole. Because the employee is so focused on work (and themselves) they have no time to properly raise a family, contribute to society, or in general be a "good" person. Instead they likely use their few spare hours a week to buy items to make themselves feel better. The only winner in this case is the corporation.

The automobile analogy is a bit broken. The germans have some of the top car manufacturers in the world yet they enforce a 40hr work week. Why is this? My theory is they work smarter not harder, and don't burn out employees for short term gains. This is something many of these new tech corporations still need to learn.

Corporate attorneys also work long hours, which is why they are paid so well, as are programmers at Amazon.

I do not understand the sympathy for educated and well paid adults who have many other jobs options, as if they are not responsible for their own career choices, but I do think the warehouse workers should unionize, as should all blue collar workers.

There is a big difference when you have no other choice in a job and I save my sympathy for those people, not a bunch of privileged and whining programmers who make six figure salaries with stock options.

A vast over-generalization of the human situation. 'No human has to eat meat to survive.' Really? Tell that one to some of my vegan friends, as a number have returned to eating meat because for them, a vegan diet did not work for their bodies. Before people trot out the hackneyed 'they did not do it right,' scenario, the people involved studied nutrition extensively and one had taken a course designed to transition to veganism. She almost died.

People are part of the animal kingdom and some animals, including people, consume meat. Vegans put humanity onto artificial pedestals. Some animals are omnivores, including humans. Vegans drive cars, live in homes and pontificate away on computers (all containing animal by-products), yet because they do not eat animal products, they sit on sanctimonious pedestals and condemn omnivores. We all live on the death of other organic entities, be they animal or plants. the only thing that matters is how animals are treated when they are raised for food in mono-crop production, such as palm oil, for example. Avoiding meat from factory farms is a good thing to do.

There have even been the extreme positions of some Utilitarian philosophers calling for the culling of all carnivorous species on the planet because they consume herbivores in the wild.

http://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/09/19/the-meat-eaters/

Many people eat meat and that is not going to change. Change farming methods, do away with factory farms.

A letter to Mr Bezos and his employees:
I was extremely upset and sorry to read this NYT report. I have been in the workforce for 45 years, and continue to do my part as a dedicated employee and. I hope, am a wise consumer. "Social Darwinism" as described and documented in this story horrifies me. Mr. Bezos' answer today was trivial and unconvincing. Any leader who sets up the principles described, and knows about the anonymous reporting that employees are encouraged to do on one another, must have thought of the human toll these principles and protocols would take. The "work till you drop and compete in any way possible with your colleagues" ethic is inhumane and cannot be condoned.
I empathize with your employees who are not given this care and compassion. Our democracy's social policies (Social Security etc) are based on principles that Mr. Bezos and his "best and brightest" people should reconsider.
Isn't it strange that because a customer is spending money, you agonize over our (the customers') every concern, and fail to consider the humanity of your employees?
Since money is your bottom line, please know this. I will never again spend a cent on an Amazon service until your policies change.

I read Bezos' disappointing response to this article:

"I want you to escalate to HR. You can also email me directly at jeff@amazon.com "

This is not a solution. These problems won't be fixed by dealing with one off individual cases. Bezos knows that. He knows you don't fix problems by just having the expectation that people should do a better job. You fix problems by putting the right systems in place. Escalate to HR and email the CEO are already available, and yet this garbage happens all the time. He provides no systematic or organizational change to address the issues brought to light by this article. This is a non-response.

"I strongly believe that anyone working in a company that really is like the one described in the NYT would be crazy to stay. I know I would leave such a company."

This is also not a solution to the culture problem at Amazon, but a telling example of how Amazon got to be the company it is today. For each decent person who quits, the culture of abuse tightens. If everyone but the brutal quit, the company will be made up of no one but the most brutal.

Retail is brutal, more so than the military. It is like cage fighting.

Workers are not "drones". And the article gives a job description for everyone interviewed. For more about what work was done in the early days of Amazon, see "Amazonia" by James Marcus. See also: "The Everything Store: Jeff Bezos and the Age of Amazon" by Brad Stone.

Fascinating, disturbing article. But what do these drones actually DO?  What are their tasks during a typical day? How are their hours organized? What are their specific areas of responsibility? What are their expected outcomes and how are they measured? In other words, what - exactly - IS this alternative reality? George Orwell, please come back.

"L", I take your points. However, many managers of corporations large and small are clueless as to the impact they have on their companies and their employees. That's how they get through the day and feel no regrets when the accept 100 million dollar retirement or departure packages. There is a distortion field around the brain that prevents facts from entering.

Several yrs. ago, I watched the very first episode of "Undercover Boss" on CBS. This is a show where the top guy pretends to be a low level employee getting experience within the company. The guy who was the boss on that first show, whose name I now forget, seemed a decent fellow, but if you paid attention closely, it was beyond question that he had no idea how his decisions were being handed down and how much impact they had and, further, no idea of the hard work and struggles of the lower economic set who get by week by week running on burned out energy and exhausted hopes.

We are becoming a nation where cruelty, exploitation and quick termination are the norms, not the exception. These are the processes whereby bosses get gigantic bonuses bigger than the lifetime pay of most workers, shareholders get dividends and higher prices and, before yesterday, Jeff Bezos got profiled repeatedly as one of the smartest, most effective business leaders in the world. Like Walmart, nothing can really touch Amazon except a truly massive turning away of customers, declining share prices and class action lawsuits.

And this does not even begin to describe the conditions and treatment of their employees at their shipping and warehouse facilities.
